discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Sybil resistance for Recognized Delegates

content.content: MakerDAO’s delegate compensation is paid out based on a quadratic formula. Each increasing MKR that is delegated to an individual Recognized Delegate (RD) is worth less when it comes to calculating compensation until 10k MKR is delegated, at which point each additional MKR is valued at zero and the comp maxes out. Due to this math, there is a considerable incentive for individuals or organizations to attempt to game the delegation compensation system by creating multiple Recognized Delegate addresses under pseudonyms. For instance, it is far more lucrative to have 2 Recognized Delegate accounts with 5k MKR delegated to each (comp: 16,970 DAI/mo) as opposed to 1 account with 10k MKR delegated (comp: 12,000 DAI/mo). As political factions grow within the DAO, there is also more opportunity for 1 person, with 1 unique set of principles, to create multiple pseudonymous RD accounts, feigning different sets of DAO-related values to appease various ideologies when it comes to the future of the DAO. Gitcoin has faced a very similar situation over the past few years and created this nice 2-minute explainer of the problem:     To pursue stronger incentive alignment and a more genuine governance system, should the DAO consider putting new and existing RDs through some sort of sybil resistance check (i.e. Gitcoin Passport) to work toward ensuring that each RD is a unique human or organization and that it’s more difficult for a single human/org to benefit from more than 1 RD account?     Yes No Abstain     0 voters     NOTE: Restarted the poll after being live for 10 min because I failed to enable public voting initially.

content.content: I probably should have been a bit clearer in my initial post. This isn’t about doxxing anyone with facial scanning or anything like that. This is about doing our best to ensure that a RD has a pre-existing reputation and is vouched for by others before they become an RD. This shouldn’t prohibit anons from becoming RDs in any way. The Gitcoin model is to give options to have your social reputation vouched for in a way that would allow people like Hasu to easily pass, and keep someone who created an anon identity specifically to only use on the Maker forum out of the RD program. Gitcoin Passport docs are a good place to start learning more about easy ways to implement this.

content.content: I voted yes because I have known this was an issue even since the start of the delegation compensation initiative.   I felt the simplest way to handle the MKR sybil compensation issue was to both unify MKR compensation (for all governance participants) and to make rewards linear to MKR voting as per my delegate thread post.   Put simply sybil’s only matter when one deviates from rewards being linear to MKR held or capped in some way. content.content: threadreaderapp.com    Thread by @chunza2542 on Thread Reader App @chunza2542: A Complete Introduction to Gitcoin Passport 🛂 What is a @gitcoin passport? What problem does it solve? And how will it become an essential building block for a decentralized society? Let's dive in! 🧵👇 1...…      Found a solid thread on Github Passport. It’s more or less a web-of-trust model where your personal score increases by verifying the legitimacy of other participants. It looks like to initially onboard, users have the option of connecting an ENS, Google, or a Proof of Humanity account.  TLDR: “Gitcoin Passport is an identity aggregator that allows users to verify personhood, help defends against the Sybil attack, and encourage DAO to build more on a one-human-one-vote scheme.”  Passport utilizes “Quadratic funding” (QF), which allocates funds based on the sum of an individual or team’s contribution to each project.  image1200×549 71.1 KB  The main benefit of QF is that the number of contributions (to a grant) matter more than the amount funded, pushing protocol power closer to the edges.  Per the thread, the best way to handle Sybil resistance is to increase the cost of the attack - be it time, money, or effort. This can be accomplished in a number of ways.  Identify adversarial patterns that force attackers to place increased effort into the impersonation of legit ID. Increase the transaction or entry fee. ID and personhood verification.  Great post @ChrisBlec, and whether or not Passport is specifically used, I’m in favor of the web of trust model as a future implementation.

content.content: Wouldn’t it be better to use Proof of Humanity? That verifies the identity on the blockchain and that’s it?

Proof of Humanity is incorporated into the Gitcoin Passport, so it would be one of the options available if we adopted that specific tool. My main issue with using Proof of Humanity on its own is that it is not anon-friendly because it requires users to appear on video. I would prefer a solution allowing anons to verify unique humanity if possible as that would be more in keeping with the ethos of a DAO.
